translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The One Who Should Be Properly Roamed Around
“I ask the sage of abundant wisdom,
The one who has gone beyond the three, attained Nibbāna, and is steadfast;
Having gone forth from the home life, renouncing sensual pleasures,

original: Kathaṁ bhikkhu sammā so loke paribbajeyya”.
analyzed: katham bhikkhu sammā saḥ loke paribbajeyya
translated: How should a monk properly roam around in the world?”
“For one who has abandoned all auspicious things,
(so said the Blessed One)
Auspicious signs, portents, and dreams;
Free from the faults of auspicious things,
He should properly roam around in the world.
One should subdue passion for humans,
And also for heavenly sensual pleasures, O monk;
Having gone beyond existence, having realized the Dhamma,
He should properly roam around in the world.
Having thoroughly cut off slander,
A monk should abandon anger and resentment;
Free from conformity and opposition,

original: Sammā so loke paribbajeyya.🔽Hitvāna piyañca appiyañca,
analyzed: sammā saḥ loke paribbajeyya  hitvāna piyañca appiyañca
translated: He should properly roam around in the world.🔽Having abandoned what is dear and what is not dear,
Not clinging, not dependent on anything;
Liberated from the fetters,
He should properly roam around in the world.
He does not cling to the attachments,
Having removed desire and passion for the objects of sense,

analyzed: saḥ a nissitaḥ an añña neyyaḥ
translated: He who is unattached, not clinging to anything,
He would rightly wander about in the world.
By speech, by mind, and by body,
Not opposing, having understood the Dhamma,
Aspiring to the state of Nibbāna,
He would rightly wander about in the world.

original: Yo vandati manti nunnameyya,🔽Akkuṭṭhopi na sandhiyetha bhikkhu;

translated: He who pays homage, who is humble and reverential,🔽The monk who is not quarrelsome,
Who is not intoxicated with obtaining food from others,
He would rightly wander about in the world.

original: Lobhañca bhavañca vippahāya,🔽Virato chedanabandhanā ca bhikkhu;

translated: Having abandoned greed and attachment to existence,🔽The monk who abstains from cutting and binding,
He who has crossed over doubt and is free from confusion,
He would rightly wander about in the world.
Having understood his own nature,

original: No ca bhikkhu hiṁseyya kañci loke;
analyzed: no ca bhikkhu hiseyya kañci loke
translated: The monk who would not harm anyone in the world,
Having understood the Dhamma as it really is,
He would rightly wander about in the world.
He who has no latent tendencies at all,
And has uprooted the unwholesome roots,
He who is without aspiration and expectation,
He would rightly wander about in the world.
Having destroyed the pollutants, having given up conceit,
He has gone beyond all the paths of passion.
Subdued, he is fully extinguished, steadfast.
He would rightly wander in the world.
Faithful, learned, seeing the right way,

analyzed: vagga gatesu na vagga sāri dhīraḥ
translated: The wise one does not side with factions.
Having given up greed, hate, and contempt,
He would rightly wander in the world.🔽Pure, with his dart withdrawn,

translated: In control of his mind, unruffled,
Skilled in the knowledge of the cessation of volitional formations,
He would rightly wander in the world.
In the past and in the future,
Beyond the scope of time, his wisdom is pure.
Freed from all sense spheres,
He would rightly wander in the world.
Having understood the state of peace, having seen the Dhamma,
Having seen the opening, having abandoned the effluents,
With the destruction of all fetters,
He would rightly wander in the world.”
